This is a test.`; const noBreaks = str.replace(/\n/g, ''); console.log(noBreaks); // "Helloworld!This is a test." ``` The reason we dont do this automatically is bc some customers use them instead of

messages.author: haakam21
messages.content:
Hi Shep, there are many factors that go into deliverability including the infrastructure you use to send. Some things you can do maxmimize deliverability:
 - Send 10-20 emails per inbox per day
 - Have 10-20 inboxes per domain
 - Use email warmup services such as Instantly - which AgentMail is compatiable with
 - Have a CTA to reply to the email - when people reply it builds your reputation with Gmail and Outlook
 - Minimize the number of links you send
 - Avoid content that could be considered spam (overly markety or sensitive information)

messages.author: markding
messages.content: experiencing a little slow on email webhook side (around 30s), is there any way we can improve or track?

messages.author: haakam21
messages.content: The timestamp attribute of a message is the when the message was sent from the sending mail server. We are working on updating the schemas to include a created_at attribute. The difference between the two will tell you our internal processing time (coming soon). Note, however, Gmail and other providers add a delay after you press the send button to when the email actually gets sent. This delay can be 20-30 seconds. So if this is what you measuring from it is not something we can improve.

messages.author: haakam21
messages.content: You can change Gmail settings to reduce (but not eliminate) this delay

messages.author: haakam21
messages.content: <@317880338720489472> Figured our the issue and fixed it. We listen to insert events in our database to send `message.received` webhooks. As our traffic has grown we now regularly have multiple such events happening at the same time. These events get rolled up into batches to be processed. However, when processing a batch, an exception with one event caused the remaining events in the batch to be not processed. Have now isolated exception handling for each event. Thank you for bringing this to our attention!

messages.author: haakam21
messages.content: Hi Jason, the timestamp of a message is the timestamp of when it was sent from the sending email provider. If you subscribe to the `message.received` webhook you could measure the time it takes for your servers to receive the webhook from when the message was sent. Note that this time difference would include time it takes for sending mail server to deliver the message to our mail server, time it takes for our mail server to process the message, and time for the webhook to be delivered to your server.

messages.author: harryduu_61189
messages.content:
Good question! The example shows localhost for development, but for production you'll need a publicly accessible URL.
For Vercel deployment:
1. Deploy your webhook handler as a Vercel serverless function
2. Use your Vercel URL (e.g., `https://your-app.vercel.app/api/webhook`) in AgentMail webhook settings
3. Make sure to set environment variables (API keys) in Vercel dashboard

messages.author: harryduu_61189
messages.content:
Hey ndr! Two options:
Op 1: Google Workspace Routing (Requires a paid Google Workspace account)
You can configure email routing in the Google Admin console to forward specific addresses to AgentMail.
Op 2: Use a subdomain (simpler)
Create a subdomain like mail.yourdomain.com and set its MX records to point only to AgentMail. No conflict with Gmail since they're separate subdomains.

messages.author: namish5918
messages.content: What is the recommended way to handle file attachments? My agent needs to download that to a sandbox environment

messages.author: harryduu_61189
messages.content:
Hey Namish!  The `get_attachment` API returns the file directly. To save it in your sandbox:
```python
from agentmail import AgentMail

client = AgentMail(api_key="...")

# Returns file bytes
file_content = client.inboxes.messages.get_attachment(
    inbox_id="...",
    message_id="...",
    attachment_id="..."
)

# Save to sandbox
with open("/path/to/file.pdf", "wb") as f:
    f.write(file_content)
```
What sandbox are you using? Happy to help with specifics.

messages.author: _kahono_
messages.content: Hello. We am using agentmail to send outreach emails on behalf of some companies. During the testing phase, we realised that most of the emails we are sending were going to spam. Are there guidelines we can follow / things we should to so that we avoid emails going to spam?

messages.author: _kahono_
messages.content: Need more help

messages.author: simplehacker1313
messages.content:
Hi Jackson, happy to help! For outreach, you should do the following:
1. Warm up your inboxes using a provider like Instantly
2. Use a number of custom domain
3. Personalize copy (no links, no tracking, concise, clear CTA)

Using the default "agentmail.to" domain for outreach would probably not suffice for your use case. I'd recommend upgrading here if youd like to do outreach
